entry.title: Combined summary - Three Month bitcoin-dev Moderation Review
entry.summary: The Bitcoin-dev mailing list recently had discussions on the usefulness of comments in technical conversations. Members suggested that technical comments should contribute uniquely to the conversation and not simply repeat what has already been said. A simple +1 without any added explanation was deemed unhelpful and not useful. The goal is to provide readers with another thing to consider in favor of something beyond just the number of people who support it. Evidence trumps votes.Rusty Russell questioned the moderation rules that discouraged "+1s" but clarified that providing a technical explanation of agreement is acceptable. Rusty recommended amending the rules to clarify that "+1s" are not allowed without an explanation. Peter Todd also suggested that technical comments should contribute uniquely to the discussion and not simply repeat what has already been said.Additionally, the email thread included a three-month review of moderation on the Bitcoin-dev mailing list. Participants were asked to consider what moderation should look like going forward, including if moderation should stop altogether, if it should be more/less harsh, if a different method/criteria should be used, if moderators should be added/removed, and any other improvements. Xor believed that the prohibition of "+1s" is likely to push actual decision-making to IRC, making it less accessible to people due to high traffic.Gavin offered his services as a techie for those in need and shared information about his projects Litmocracy and Meme Racing, both of which are currently in alpha. The example given is a +1 with relevant data from Jane Doe, CTO of CoinBitChainBasely.com, which highlights how their company could have prevented customer support tickets.Finally, the email list for bitcoin-dev underwent a three-month review of moderation, with changes made to the moderation plan such as not clearing the "needs mod" bit after first posts and answering trivially answerable emails or proposals in the reject message itself. Participants are asked to consider what moderation should look like going forward, including if moderation should stop altogether, if it should be more/less harsh, if a different method/criteria should be used, if moderators should be added/removed, and any other improvements. The email also discusses the difficulty in accessing moderated messages and suggests a downloadable version of these messages on the ozlabs website containing the text of the moderated emails. Overall, the goal of the conversation is to foster peer-review while ensuring that the contributions made are unique and valuable to the conversation.
